intro: Quercus compta, commonly known as the Mexican white oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its white to pale gray bark and oval, elongated leaves that are typically 4–8 inches long. The tree produces small, clustered acorns that are encased in a cupule, a feature common among oaks. It thrives in a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained, sandy soils. Quercus compta plays an important ecological role, providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
